questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with a history of epigastric pain, vomiting and peripheral edema. He also gave a history of involuntary weight loss in the last 2 months. On investigation, his serum protein level was found to be low. An endoscopy was done, and an image obtained when the scope was in the stomach is shown below. The gastric aspirate showed a decrease in the acid content of the stomach. Which part of the stomach is usually spared in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 50-year-old male who presented with epigastric pain, vomiting, peripheral edema, involuntary weight loss and hypoproteinemia with a decreased acid content of the stomach (hypochlorhydria) and endoscopy showing hypertrophied gastric mucosal folds is suggestive of Ménétrier disease which usually spares the antrum of the stomach.

Menetrier disease, also called hyperplastic hypersecretory gastropathy is a disorder of the stomach characterized by enlarged rugae (gastric folds). It is common in men and the age of onset is usually between 40-60 years. In children, it is usually associated with cytomegalovirus infection and in adults the aetiology is unknown.

Clinical features include epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, anorexia, peripheral edema, and weight loss. It occurs due to excessive secretion of transforming growth factor (TGF)-α, which stimulates the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) pathway, resulting in increased proliferation of mucus cells/foveolar hyperplasia within the body and fundus, causing enlarged gastric folds. The antrum is usually spared. 

There is excessive production of mucous in the stomach which results in increased loss of proteins (hypoproteinemia), and a decreased number of parietal cells and oxyntic glands leads to hypochlorhydria. They are at an increased risk of developing gastric carcinoma.

Histopathologic examination of the stomach shows hyperplasia of foveolar mucous cells, cystically dilated glands that are elongated (with a corkscrew-like appearance)

Diagnosis includes endoscopy with full-thickness deep mucosal biopsy. Treatment is mainly supportive, with intravenous albumin and parenteral nutritional supplementation. A gastrectomy may be required in severe cases. Drugs like cetuximab (a monoclonal antibody against EGFR) are also being tried.

questions.text: A male patient presents to your clinic with complaints of a large lesion on the back and left shoulder. There is no pain or itching associated with the lesion. On examination, there is a 15x20 cm hyperpigmented patch with irregular borders over the left shoulder and back, with hair growth over the lesion. The image of the physical examination findings is shown below. When is the onset of the lesion most likely to occur?
questions.solution:
The given stem and image show Becker's Naevus, the onset of which is usually in puberty.

Becker's naevus is an epidermal melanocytic naevus with aggregation of melanocyte clusters in the epidermis beginning in adolescence when there is an increased sensitivity to androgens especially in the distribution of outer arms, scapular area and chest. It is rarely congenital. A triad of features can be seen:

  • Hyperpigmentation
  • Hypertrichosis
  • Acne

Becker naevus can also be associated with extracutaneous abnormalities such as aplasia or hypoplasia of the underlying breast tissue, or pectoralis major muscle or lipoatrophy. In such cases, it is referred to as Becker naevus Syndrome. Other extracutaneous associations include ipsilateral limb growth disturbance, supernumer­ary nipples, and scoliosis.

questions.text: You read an article on a protective reflex that occurs during over-inflation of the lungs. Choose the true statement regarding the reflex.

choices.text: Occurs when the tidal volume reaches 1500 mL
Mediated by rapidly adapting myelinated vagal fibres
Plays a major role in regulating normal respiration

questions.solution:
The protective reflex that occurs in response to over inflation of the lung is the Hering-Breuer reflex. It is activated when the lung volume increases to more than three times the normal tidal volume (tidal volume = 0.5 liters/breath; So, lung volume > 1.5 liters per breath activates the reflex).

Hering-Breuer inflation reflex means prolonged inspiration inhibits further inspiration. Overinflation of the lung activates the pulmonary stretch receptors. Signals from these receptors travel through the vagus nerve and inhibit the inspiratory ramp signals in dorsal respiratory group of neurons. This also increases the respiratory rate. It is a protective mechanism and prevents over inflation of the lungs.

Hering-Breuer inflation reflex: "Prolonged inspiration inhibits further inspiration"

Hyperinflation of lungs stimulates slowly adapting pulmonary stretch receptors and the impulses travel in the vagus nerve via large myelinated fibers.

This signal inhibits the inspiratory ramp signals of the dorsal respiratory group of neurons (DRG), thus, inspiration is quickly inhibited and expiration follows.

It also increases the rate of respiration.

The Hering-Breuer reflex is activated when the lung volume increases to more than three times the normal tidal volume (tidal volume = 0.5 liters/breath; So, lung volume > 1.5 liters per breath activates the reflex).

It signifies that the reflex plays a protective role preventing the overinflation of the lung rather than regulating the normal ventilation. 

Advantages of Hering-Breuer inflation reflex: It cuts down the inspiration time, and therefore,

  • It prevents overinflation of the lungs.
  • Lungs operate at lower lung volumes, thereby preventing wastage of energy.

Hering-Breuer deflation reflex- A decrease in the duration of expiration in response to marked deflation of the lung.

questions.text:
A professor demonstrates the following reflex on a healthy newborn. Match the correct pairs regarding this reflex.
Condition Reflex
  1. Stage I HIE
  2. Stage III HIE
  3. Erb's palsy
  4. Hydranencephaly
  1. Absent 
  2. Asymmetric
  3. Brisk 
  4. Exaggerated 

HIE - Hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy
questions.solution:
The reflex shown in the image is Moro reflex. Option C is correctly matched.

  1. Stage I HIE - Brisk Moro reflex
  2. Stage III HIE - Absent moro reflex
  3. Erb's palsy - Asymmetric Moro reflex
  4. Hydranencephaly - Exaggerated Moro reflex

The above-animated GIF shows a normal response to Moro's reflex: symmetrical extension and abduction of the upper extremities, followed by flexion of the upper extremities.

 The Moro reflex:

  • It is a primitive reflex that is very sensitive to the infant's level of alertness.
  • It can be elicited by supporting the infant in the semierect position and allowing the infant’s head to fall backward onto the examiner’s hand.

Absent Moro reflex: caused by significant generalized disturbance of the CNS

  • Stage III HIE (Hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy)
  • Kernicterus

Asymmetric Moro reflex: Feature of the root, plexus, or nerve disease

  • Fractured clavicle
  • Brachial plexus injury (Erb's palsy)
  • Hemiparesis

Brisk Moro reflex 

  • Neonatal hypoglycemia
  • It can also be a normal variant in healthy infants
  • Stage I HIE (Hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy)

Exaggerated, stereotyped, non-habituating Moro reflex is a feature of severe bilateral intrauterine cerebral disturbance, perhaps because of the release of the brain stem from inhibitory cortical influences. It is seen in conditions such as the following:

  • Hydranencephaly
  • Severe micrencephaly vera

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman came with complaints of massive painless vaginal bleeding. She also reported amenorrhea for 2 months. The histopathological examination of the endometrium showed a characteristic Swiss cheese pattern. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario history of painless vaginal bleeding preceded by amenorrhea with histopathological examination of the endometrium revealing a characteristic Swiss cheese pattern is suggestive of metropathia hemorrhagica.

Metropathia hemorrhagica is a specialized form of anovulatory DUB, seen in women aged 40 to 45 years. The typical symptoms are continuous painless vaginal bleeding at the onset of menses or preceded by a 6-8 week period of amenorrhoea. Occasionally the woman gives a history of menorrhagia prior to this.

On examination, the uterus is bulky and uniformly enlarged. Histopathological findings are:

  • Myohyperplasia of the uterine wall - up to 2.5cm
  • Thick endometrium with cystic glandular hyperplasia appearing as Swiss cheese pattern
  • Absence of secretory endometrium i.e. absence of corkscrew glands 
  • Thin, slender endometrial polyps project into the uterine cavity
  • Corpus luteum is absent
  • One or both ovaries may contain a cyst

Other options

Option A: Endometriosis usually presents in the reproductive age group, with symptoms of dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, menorrhagia, and infertility.

Option C: Halban's disease is irregular shedding and is due to persistent corpus luteum. Regular cycles with prolonged bleeding and normal flow are present. 

Option D: Endometrial carcinoma usually presents as postmenopausal bleeding. There may be a history of PCOS or HRT indicating chronic estrogen exposure. There will be no Swiss cheese appearance on histopathological examination.

questions.text: A 44-year-old HIV patient presents with a non-productive cough and progressively worsening breathing difficulty. Chest x-ray shows diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates along with a pneumatocele. Microscopic examination of the bronchoalveolar lavage shows the following. What is the special stain used in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the staining showing the black-colored stained cysts, resembling the crushed ping pong balls, are suggestive of Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP). It is caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii. The stain used for staining the causative organism is Gomori’s methenamine silver stain.

Patients with PCP generally present with fever and cough that is usually non-productive. Finding on chest x-ray is either a normal film if the disease is suspected early, or diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates. The classic finding of dense perihilar infiltrate is unusual in patients with AIDS.

Treatment: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and pentamidine isethionate

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the ED after being involved in a high-speed motorcycle collision. He is hypotensive with a systolic pressure of 60 mm Hg. A FAST scan is positive. At laparotomy, he is found to have a large amount of bleeding from behind the liver with hollow-viscous perforation. Temporary application of a Pringle manoeuvre does not control the bleeding. However, laparotomy packs are placed, and the bleeding appears to slow down. The systolic blood pressure fails to increase even after aggressive resuscitation. The patient’s pH is 7.06 and his temperature is 34°C. What would be the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has a blunt trauma abdomen. He is hypothermic and he is battling acidosis. Thus, he should be subjected to damage control surgery and must be shifted to ICU for further resuscitation. 

Damage control surgery is minimal intervention done to stabilize the patient and do the definite surgery later. It centers on coordinating staged operative interventions with periods of aggressive resuscitation to salvage trauma patients sustaining major injuries.

3 Phases  :

Phase I (Initial Exploration) -

This phase consists of an initial operative exploration to attain rapid control of active hemorrhage and contamination.

Phase II (Secondary Resuscitation) -

This phase focuses on secondary resuscitation to correct hypothermia, coagulopathy, and acidosis. 

Phase III (Definitive Operation) -

It consists of planned re-exploration and definitive repair of injuries. This phase typically occurs 48 to 72 hours following initial and after successful secondary resuscitation.

Pringle's manoeuvre can be performed to decrease the active haemorrhage from the liver in a liver laceration. It is done by applying pressure on the portal triad at the Foramen of Winslow. The pressure can be applied either digitally or with the use of a soft clamp. 

Rapid control of the vessels entering the porta hepatis can be obtained by compressing them in the free edge of the lesser omentum.

Porta hepatis is a deep, transverse fissure that is situated on the inferior surface of the right lobe of the liver.

Structures entering at porta hepatis:

  • Portal vein
  • Hepatic artery
  • Hepatic nervous plexus

Structures exiting the porta hepatis:

  • Right and left hepatic bile ducts
  • Lymphatics

The images attached below shows the porta hepatis and the gif demonstrates the pringles manoeuvre. 

4 P's in the management of liver injuries are: 

  • Push- Compression of the edges of the laceration
  • Pringle- Applying pressure on the portal triad
  • Plug the defects with silicon tubes
  • Pack- Apply packs in and around the liver to arrest bleeding

General guidelines for the management of blunt trauma to the liver:

  • Patients who are haemodynamically unstable will require an immediate laparotomy for damage control resuscitation. 
  • For the patient who is haemodynamically stable, imaging by CT should be performed to further evaluate the nature of the injury.
  • Most patients with a blunt liver injury who are haemodynamically stable can be managed conservatively.
  • The indication for discontinuing conservative treatment is the development of haemodynamic instability, evidence of ongoing blood loss despite correction of any underlying coagulopathy and the development of signs of generalised peritonitis.
  • Interventional radiology has an important role in the management of liver trauma and embolisation to control hepatic artery bleeding is safe and effective in a stable patient with no evidence of hollow viscus perforation.

Related Pearl: Damage Control Surgery

Five stages of damage control surgery:

1. Patient selection
2. Control of hemorrhage and control of contamination
3. Resuscitation continued in the intensive care unit
4. Deﬁnitive surgery
5. Abdominal closure

Phases of Damage Control Surgery:

Phase 0: Identification of patient for damage control surgery in emergency room
Phase 1: Emergency laparotomy to stop bleeding and prevent contamination
Phase 2: ICU care for resuscitation
Phase 3: Re-laparotomy for definitive repair

Indications for damage control surgery:

Anatomical

  • Inability to achieve haemostasis
  • Complex abdominal injury, e.g. liver and pancreas
  • Combined vascular, solid and hollow organ injury, e.g. aortic or caval injury
  • Inaccessible major venous injury, e.g. retrohepatic vena cava
  • Demand for non-operative control of other injuries, e.g. fractured pelvis
  • Anticipated need for a time-consuming procedure

Physiological (decline of physiological reserve)

  • Temperature <34ºC
  • pH <7.2
  • Serum lactate >5 mmol/L (normal is <2.5 mmol/L)
  • Prothrombin time (PT) >16 s
  • Partial thromboplastin time (PTT) >60 s
  • Blood transfusion approaching 15 units
  • Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg for >60 min

Environmental

  • Operating time >60 min
  • Inability to approximate the abdominal incision
  • Desire to reassess the intra-abdominal contents (directed relook)

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about thallium poisoning?

choices.text: It gives no odour after death
It is an ideal homicidal agent
It can be detected in the ashes of the burnt body

questions.solution:
In thallium poisoning, postmortem examination reveals a garlicky odour from the mouth and nose. 

Thallium is odourless, tasteless, and water-soluble. The poisoning with this metal closely resembles a natural disease. Therefore, this is an ideal homicidal poison.

Thallium salts are used in dye and glass industries and as rodenticides and insecticides. In mild cases, joint pain, loss of appetite and drowsiness can occur. In severe cases, there is colicky pain, hair loss, vomiting, severe muscle and joint pains, motor and sensory neuropathies, convulsions, psychosis, optic neuritis, tremors delirium and coma. Madarosis (loss of outer third of eyebrows) is significant. Death occurs due to respiratory paralysis. On postmortem examination, it has a garlic-like odour, Mees lines may be present on nail. It can also be detected in the ashes of the burnt body i.e. after cremation.

Chronic thallium poisoning has a triad of alopecia, skin rashes, painful peripheral neuropathy and mental confusion with lethargy.

Treatment is mainly by stomach wash with potassium iodide or Prussian blue, activated charcoal. Hemodialysis is useful and forced diuresis can be given.

questions.text: A 10-month-old baby is brought to the pediatric department with characteristic hair as shown in the image. Further examination shows that the child has truncal hypotonia, and failure to thrive. Which of the following genetic mutation will be seen in this child?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the image showing an irritable child with kinky colorless, and sparse hair with truncal hypotonia on examination is suggestive of Menke's disease. It is due to a defect in the ATP7A gene on chromosome X.

Menkes disease is a rare X-linked recessive progressive multisystemic disease of copper metabolism. In this condition, dietary copper is absorbed from the GI tract but it cannot be transported to blood due to the absence of an intracellular copper binding ATPase (mutation in ATP7A gene). Copper deficiency results in the defective function of the lysyl oxidase enzyme and thus leading to reduced cross-linkage of collagen.

Note :

  • ATP7A: Menkes disease - X-linked                 
  • ATP7B: Wilson's disease - Autosomal recessive (Chromosome 13) (Option D)

Other options-

Option (A) and (B) are not associated with disorders of copper absorption.

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: A patient presents to the clinic with a history of fever, body pains, and cough for the past 3 days. On examination, his SpO2 is found to be 89% on room air and his respiratory rate is 32 per minute. Rapid antigen test for COVID-19 is found to be positive. You admit the patient for the treatment of the infection. Which of the following is true regarding the management of this patient?

choices.text: Enoxaparin 0.1mg/kg per dose twice a day
D-dimer levels assessment once in 5 days
Liver function tests once a week

questions.solution:
The above patient has a severe infection of COVID-19. His SpO2 is <90% on room air and his respiratory rate is more than 30 minutes. He should be administered inj. methylprednisolone 1 to 2mg/kg IV in two divided doses.

Management of severe COVID-19 infection

  • Symptomatic treatment with paracetamol and antitussives.
  • Maintain euvolemia, use conservative fluid management in patients with severe covid when there is no evidence of shock.
  • Respiratory support with supplemental oxygen, non-invasive ventilation, or intubation.
  • Inj methylprednisolone 1 to 2mg/kg IV in 2 divided doses (or 0.2-0.4mg/kg of dexamethasone) usually for a duration 5 to 10 days.
  • Prophylactic use of unfractionated heparin or low molecular weight heparin-like enoxaparin 0.5mg/kg per dose twice a day subcutaneously.
  • A serial chest radiograph should be taken to monitor. High-resolution CT chest to be done only if there is worsening of symptoms
  • Lab monitoring: C- reactive protein and D-dimer levels should be assessed 24-48 hourly. Complete blood count, renal function tests, and liver function tests should be assessed daily. If the patient's condition is deteriorating and the laboratory facilities are available, the estimation of IL-6 is to be done.

Classification of Covid19 infection severity according to Ministry of Health and family welfare.

Mild- patients with uncomplicated upper respiratory tract infection, may have mild symptoms such as fever, cough, sore throat, nasal congestion, malaise, headache. There is no shortness of breath or hypoxia.

Moderate- patient with signs of pneumonia but without signs of severe disease. Adults with the presence of clinical features of dyspnea and or hypoxia, fever, cough, including SpO2 90 to ≤93% on room air, the respiratory rate more or equal to 24 per minute.

Severe- Adults with clinical signs of pneumonia plus one of the following; respiratory rate >30 breaths/min, severe respiratory distress, SpO2 <90% on room air.

Severe infection further has:

  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)- it is defined by
    • patients develop new or worsening respiratory symptoms within one week of onset of the symptoms.
    • There are opacities in the chest radiographs which are not due to effusions, lobar or lung collapse, or nodules.
    • The patients develop respiratory failure which is not due to cardiac failure or fluid overload. The PaO2/FiO2 ≤ 300 mmHg (with PEEP or CPAP ≥5 cm H2O)
  • ARDS can be further classified as
    • Mild ARDS: 200 mmHg < PaO2/FiO2 ≤ 300 mmHg (with PEEP or CPAP ≥5 cm H2O)
    • Moderate ARDS: 100 mmHg < PaO2/FiO2 ≤200 mmHg with PEEP ≥5 cm H2O)
    • Severe ARDS: PaO2/FiO2 ≤ 100 mmHg with PEEP ≥5 cm H2O)
  • Sepsis
  • Septic shock

questions.text: A 23-year-old college student sustained a knee injury in the basketball match in the sports fest. The orthopaedic resident performed the Lachman test which turned out to be positive. Identify the ligament affected.
questions.solution:
The positive Lachman's test is suggestive of injury to the anterior cruciate ligament, which is marked as 'A' in the image shown.

The anterior cruciate ligament is attached to the anterior intercondylar area of the tibia. It ascends posterolaterally, twisting on itself and fanning out to attach high on the posteromedial aspect of the lateral femoral condyle.

Lachman's Test:

The patient’s knee is flexed 20-30 degrees, with one hand grasping the lower thigh and the other the upper part of the leg. The joint surfaces are shifted backwards and forwards upon each other.

The abnormal movement, as shown in the video below, suggests an anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury. If the knee is stable, there should be no gliding.

questions.text: A child with bilateral cataracts was brought to the ophthalmology department. Systemic examination reveals hearing loss, a congenital heart defect along with the following lesions that have been present since birth. All of the following are the ocular findings associated with this condition except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing blueberry muffin lesions is suggestive of Congenital rubella syndrome and microphthalmos is seen in this condition (not megalophthalmos).

Congenital rubella cataract may occur alone or as part of the classical rubella syndrome which consists of:

  • Ocular defects: Congenital cataract, salt and pepper chorioretinopathy, microphthalmos, Glaucoma, and anterior uveitis
  • Sensorineural hearing loss
  • Heart defects: Patent ductus arteriosus, pulmonary stenosis, and ventricular septal defects.

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a sudden loss of vision in both eyes that occurred after a stressful argument with her boss. On examination, her visual acuity is recorded as 6/6 in each eye, and her pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light. There are no abnormalities found on ophthalmic examination or in other neurological evaluations. When asked to follow a moving object or identify visual stimuli, she demonstrates inconsistent performance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette given is conversion disorder /functional neurologic symptom disorder.

Conversion disorder is a condition with symptoms or deficits that involve voluntary motor or sensory functions. Though it points to an underlying medical condition, in reality, it arises due to psychological factors. The symptoms are not intentionally produced and the gain obtained is primarily psychological. 

It can be associated with depressive disorders, anxiety disorders, personality disorders, and somatization disorders. Paralysis, blindness, and mutism are the most frequently seen conversion disorder symptoms. Anaesthesia and paresthesia of the extremities, abnormal movements, and gait disturbance are the other features commonly seen. 

Conversion disorder usually resolves spontaneously. Insight-oriented or behavioural therapy is also helpful. Hypnosis and anxiolytics are used in some cases. 

Other options: 

Option B: Catatonia is a condition seen in advanced primary mood or psychotic illnesses. Some conditions that can cause catatonia include head trauma, encephalitis, and hepatic encephalopathy. Some medications such as corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, or antipsychotics can also result in the condition. Some clinical features include grimacing, mutism, echolalia, stupor, and posturing.

Option C: Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO), especially in its ischemic form, usually presents with severe visual loss, marked retinal haemorrhages, cotton wool spots, optic disc oedema, and a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), often accompanied by detectable abnormalities on ophthalmic examination. However, this patient has normal visual acuity, normal pupillary reactions, and no detectable abnormalities on ophthalmic or neurological exams, making CRVO an unlikely diagnosis in this case.

Option D: Eales' disease, common in young Asian males, features recurrent vitreous haemorrhage and retinal neovascularization due to peripheral retinal vein inflammation. It presents with a reddish vitreous mass and can lead to vision loss and complications like retinal detachment. However, it is less likely here due to the patient’s demographics and absence of characteristic findings.

Related Pearl: Conversion Disorder

Conversion disorder: Also called functional neurological symptom disorder.

Common presenting symptoms:

  • Weakness and/or paralysis
  • Non-epileptic seizures
  • Movement disorders
  • Speech or visual impairment like mutism or blindness
  • Swallowing difficulty
  • Sensory disturbances
  • Cognitive symptoms

Diagnostic criteria:

  • Symptoms of altered neurological function-voluntary motor or sensory
  • Often precipitated by a psychological stressor (the temporal relationship between stressor and symptoms is present)
  • Not feigned or intentionally produced (as in factitious disorder or malingering)
  • Findings incompatible with a recognized neurological condition
  • Symptoms cause significant social or occupational impairment

Other important features:

  • Primary gain - Unconscious relief from stress as the focus of the patient shifts to the symptoms.
  • Secondary gain - Attention gained by the patient (from bystanders) as a result of the symptoms.
  • La-belle indifference - refers to an absence of concern towards one’s problem despite severe disability
  • Astasia abasia - Wildly ataxic, staggering gait accompanied by irregular, jerky truncal movements, thrashing and waving arm movements

Management options:

  • First-line: Education and self-help technique
  • Second-line: Cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Physical therapy for motor symptoms

Related Pearl: Somatoform Disorder

Somatoform Disorder

questions.text: A surgery resident during the rounds advised the intern to monitor the burns patient for adequate fluid resuscitation and also instructed him to give a bolus of 10 mL/kg body weight if the patient showed signs of hypoperfusion. All of the following are indications to give bolus fluid, except:
questions.solution:
A low hematocrit does not indicate a need for fluid resuscitation.

Instead, a high hematocrit is an indicator of hypoperfusion. 

Urine output is the best measure to monitor for the adequacy of fluid resuscitation. Urine output should be between 0.5 and 1.0 mL/kg body weight per hour. If the urine output is below this, the infusion rate should be increased by 50%. If the urine output is inadequate and the patient is showing signs of hypoperfusion, then a bolus of 10 mL/kg body weight should be given.

Signs of hypoperfusion include:

  • Restlessness with tachycardia,
  • Cool peripheries 
  • High hematocrit

questions.text: A patient is posted for an ambulatory surgery and the following agent is used for intravenous induction of anesthesia. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the agent shown in the image below?

choices.text: It causes pain on intravenous injection
Increases the risk of post-operative nausea and vomiting
Used as sedation for mechanically ventilated patients

questions.solution:
The anesthetic agent used in this patient for induction is propofol which appears as a milky white liquid as shown in the image. Propofol has antiemetic properties which help reduce post-operative nausea and vomiting.

Its constituents are:

  • 1% propofol
  • 1.2% egg phospholipid (emulsifier)
  • 2.25% glycerol (Tonicity adjusting agent)
  • 10% soya bean oil 
  • NaOH (to change pH)
  • EDTA (bacteriostatic)

Propofol is formulated as a lipid emulsion, which causes pain on injection. A new aqueous prodrug, fospropofol is associated with less pain on injection. Propofol should be handled with sterile techniques as it has a risk of growth of bacteria.

Propofol facilitates the inhibitory neurotransmission by action on GABA-A receptors. It has a rapid onset of action (within 15 sec). Induction dose is usually 1-2 mg/ kg and maintenance dose is 100-200 µg/ kg/ min.

Effects on CNS:

  • It is cerebro-protective. Reduces intracranial pressure and cerebral blood flow.
  • Anticonvulsant properties
  • Has anti-emetic properties at a dose of 10-20mg.

Other effects:

  • Produce hypotension and bradycardia; hence dose reduction is needed in elderly and hypovolemic patients.
  • Produce apnea since it is a profound respiratory depressant. 
  • Anti-pruritic property
  • Propofol infusion syndrome: It is a rare syndrome that can happen when propofol is used for long-term sedation in young patients who are critically ill or underwent neurosurgery. Symptoms include metabolic acidosis, lipemia, and death.

It is the IV agent of choice for

  • Induction of anesthesia for neuro anesthesia and other surgeries
  • Maintenance of anesthesia in patients undergoing cardiac surgery.
  • Sedation for mechanical ventilation and minor procedures in the ICU.
  • Total iv anesthesia (TIVA) and short-term anesthesia for ambulatory surgeries 
  • Malignant hyperthermia

questions.text: Which of the following surgery is done commonly in Tubotympanic type of CSOM?
questions.solution:
Tympanoplasty is done commonly in Tubotympanic type of CSOM.

It is the eradication of disease from the middle ear and reconstruction of hearing (ossiculoplasty) with or without grafting of the tympanic membrane.

Myringoplasty is the term given for closure of perforation of tympanic membrane done to check repeated infections from external ear.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department after he fell on his outstretched hand. An X-ray was performed and is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The provided history of falling on an outstretched arm and the X-ray revealing an oblique fracture in the lower third of the radius with dislocation of the distal radio-ulnar joint point to the diagnosis of Galeazzi's fracture.

Galeazzi's fracture is the fracture of the lower third of the radius and the subluxation or dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint. This injury usually happens when one falls on an outstretched hand. 

Patients present with pain, swelling, and deformity at the lower end of the radius. On examination, the disruption of the radio-ulnar joint can be elicited by pressing the lower end of the ulna. The ulna moves down and comes back like the key of a piano (piano-key sign). 

The aim of treatment for this fracture is to preserve supination and pronation of the forearm. In children, closed reduction is usually enough to achieve perfect reduction. However, in adults, open reduction using a k-wire fixation or compression plating is usually required. It is also important to look for ulnar nerve damage.

Galeazzi's fracture can cause complications such as malunion due to displacement of the fragment. This often results in deformity and limitation in supination and pronation.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.
